abstract.text: A controller that manages a view, typically loaded from a nib file.

inlineContent.text: Memory management of top-level objects similar to that performed by the
class, taking the same care to prevent reference cycles when controls are bound to the nib file’s owner.
property, to make it easy to establish bindings in the nib to an object that isn’t yet known at nib-loading time or readily available to the code that’s doing the nib loading.
Implementing the key-value binding NSEditor informal protocol, so that apps using a view controller can easily make bound controls in the views commit or discard changes by the user.

In macOS 10.10 and later, a view controller offers a full set of life cycle methods, allowing you to manage the content of a window in a way that is on a par with iOS view controller management. These methods, presented in order here to reflect a typical cycle, are:

In addition, in macOS 10.10 and later, a view controller participates in the responder chain. You can implement action methods directly in the view controller. Corresponding actions that originate in the view controller’s view proceed up the responder chain and are handled by those methods.
Prior to OS X v10.10, a typical usage pattern for loading a nib file was to subclass
. But in macOS 10.10 and later, the
method automatically looks for a nib file with the same name as the view controller. To take advantage of this behavior, name a nib file after its corresponding view controller and pass
A view controller employs lazy loading of its view: Immediately after a view controller is loaded into memory, the value of its
method returns and just before the system calls the
A view controller is meant to be highly reusable, such as for dynamically representing various objects. For example, the
instance as the argument, and set the
object that is to be shown to the user. This allows a developer to easily create new printing accessory views using bindings and the
class’s key-value coding and key-value observing compliance. When the user dismisses a printing dialog, the

classes each send NSEditor messages to each accessory view controller to ensure that the user’s changes have been committed or discarded properly. The titles of the accessories are retrieved from the view controllers and shown to the user in menus that the user can choose from.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
The visual representation for a single data element in a collection view.
An object that controls swipe navigation and animations between views or view content.
A panel that queries the user for information such as paper type and orientation.
Adds the specified controller of an accessory view to be presented in the page setup panel.
An object that stores information that’s used to generate printed output.
The Print panel that queries the user for information about a print job.
An abstract class that forms the basis of event and command processing in AppKit.
A set of methods that support the mediation of a custom segue.
An object that manages an array of adjacent child views, and has a split view object for managing dividers between those views.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A container view controller that manages a tab view interface, which organizes multiple pages of content but displays only one page at a time.
An object that manages a custom view—known as an accessory view—in the title bar–toolbar area of a window.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
Perform layout in concert with the constraint-based layout system.
A controller that manages a view, typically loaded from a nib file.
Animation options for view transitions in a view controller.
A property wrapper that loads the view controller’s view before accessing the property.
A convenience method for adding a child view controller at the end of the
array.
An array of view controllers that are hierarchical children of the view controller.
Returns whether the receiver was able to commit any pending edits.
Attempt to commit any currently edited results of the receiver.
Causes the receiver to discard any changes, restoring the previous values.
Dismisses a presented view controller, using the same animator that presented it.
For a view controller that is part of an app extension, the app extension context.
Returns a view controller object initialized to the nib file in the specified bundle.
Inserts a specified child view controller into the
array at a specified position.
A Boolean value indicating whether the view controller’s view is loaded into memory.
Instantiates a view from a nib file and sets the value of the
property.
The nib bundle to be loaded to instantiate the receiver’s primary view.
The name of the nib file to be loaded to instantiate the receiver’s primary view.
The immediate ancestor view controller of the view controller.
The desired size of the view controller’s view, in screen units.
Called when there is a change in value of the
property of a child view controller or a presented view controller.
For a view controller that is part of an app extension, the largest allowable size for the app extension’s primary view, in screen units.
For a view controller that is part of an app extension, the smallest allowable size for the app extension’s primary view, in screen units.
For a view controller that is part of an app extension, the preferred screen origin.
Presents another view controller using a specified, custom animator for presentation and dismissal.
Presents another view controller as a popover.
Presents another view controller as a modal window, also known as an alert.
Presents another view controller as a sheet.
The view controllers, if any, that are currently presented by the view controller.
The view controller that presented the view controller or that presented its farthest ancestor view controller.
Removes a specified child controller from the view controller.
Removes the called view controller from its parent view controller.
The object whose value is presented in the receiver’s primary view.
The storyboard from which the view controller was loaded.
The localized title of the receiver’s primary view.
Performs a transition between two sibling child view controllers of the view controller.
Called during Auto Layout constraint updating to enable the view controller to mediate the process.
The view controller’s primary view.
Called when the view controller’s view is fully transitioned onto the screen.
Called after the view controller’s view is removed from the view hierarchy in a window.
Called immediately after the
method of the view controller’s view is called.
Called after the view controller’s view has been loaded into memory.
Called after the view controller’s view has been loaded into memory is about to be added to the view hierarchy in the window.
Called when the view controller’s view is about to be removed from the view hierarchy in the window.
Called just before the
method of the view controller’s view is called.
For a view controller that is part of an app extension, called when its view is about to be resized.
A controller that manages a window, usually a window stored in a nib file.
A false value.
A true value.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that displays an instance as a live view in a playground.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
